Today's featured speaker is Greg Valiant. Gregory Valiant is an assistant professor
in Stanford's computer science department.

Some of his recent projects focus
on designing algorithms for accurately inferring information
about complex distributions

when given surprisingly little data. More broadly,
his research interests are in algorithms, learning, applied probability,
statistics, and evolution.

Prior to joining Stanford, Dr. Valiant was a postdoc at
the Microsoft Lab in New England. Which focused on integrating
mathematical and algorithmic

sciences with both the social sciences and
aspects of the biomedical sciences. He received a PhD from UC Berkeley in
Computer Science and degree from Harvard.

He currently teaches CS 161 design and analysis of algorithms this
winter quarter at Stanford.

Which is part of our SCPD portfolio
offered to our industry students. So now,
I'd like to turn the floor over to Greg.

>> Okay, well thanks Stephanie,
and thanks for logging in. So today I was going to tell you
about a few perspectives on how

to get a surprising amount of
information from a given amount of data.

So, a sort of mindset that underpins
this work is the following question.

So, if you're given some data that's
drawn from a very complex distribution. So, what do you mean by complex?

Well, maybe it's a very high
dimensional distribution. Maybe if the distribution with
very large domain or alphabet,

it may be a distribution
over rare genetic mutations. Or maybe it's a distribution
with very complex dependencies,

such as natural language. Then, and oftentimes,
even if you have a lot of data,

the empirical distribution
of the data is misleading. In the case of high
dimensional distributions,

well because of the dimensionality,
you need an enormous amount of data to kind of fill out
the geometry of the space.

In the case of distributions
over very large domains, often even when you have lots of data you
still fail to observe some of the domain

elements that do arise with
non-negligible probabilities. In the case of complex dependencies,
well even when you have lots of data,

sometimes you don't actually see
all of these complex dependencies.

So in these cases, the empirical distribution of the data
you have is often misleading.

And the basic question is, well,
in this undersampled regime, can we still recover accurate information
about the underlying distributions?

What can you say about the unseen
portion of the distribution? Can you say anything about
that domain elements that you

haven't actually observed? Or in cases where maybe you can't assume
great answers to the above two questions

could you still estimate
the value of collecting more data? Could you estimate well maybe if I
were to get 10 times more data or

100 times more data I would be
able to answer these questions.

So I want to give two motivations for
this work. So the first is that even though
today's machine learning systems

are extremely impressive, currently
they still use the data they have extremely inefficiently to just
to give one concrete data point.

So humans learn to speak after
hearing roughly 50 million words. So between when you are born and
when you are three or

four or five years old, most people
hear 50 million words spoken to them. So again, this isn't distinct words.

This is 50 million utterances of words. And so after hearing these 50 million
words, most children have a good grasp of

grammar, good grasp of semantics and
they basically speak like humans.

In contrast, even the state of the art
natural language processing systems today, they're fed the entire Wikipedia corpus
over and over and over and over again.

And at the end of the day they still lack
some basic grammatical understanding.

And lack kind of sense of semantics. Okay, so even though today's machine
learning systems are very, very

impressive, they don't use information
that they have all that efficiently.

The second motivation I wanted to
mention is this apparent paradox that as the number of datasets
around us have grown and

as the sizes of these datasets have grown,
in fact we are increasingly faced with this problem of seeing these
under sample distributions.

And in the next five to ten years I think
we're going to start to see many more advances that are based upon getting
more information from the given data,

getting more information from
the data that we actually have.

So with these motivations in mind, I
wanted to discuss three sort of different settings that I've been
working on recently.

These three settings will all have
the property that for a given amount of data even when the empirical
distribution of the data is misleading,

we'll still be able to accurately say
things about the underlying distribution.

So in the first part,
which is sort of a warm up, we'll consider accepting where there

each person only has
a tiny amount of data. And we'll see that you can leverage

lots of people to improve your empirical
understanding of each person even though they only have
a little bit of data.

For the second part of the talk we'll
consider a setting where we have a sample drawn from a distribution over
an extremely large domain.

That we'll actually be able to accurately
infer the structure of the portion of the domain that we haven't
seen any samples from.

So we'll actually be able to infer things,
but the number of unseen domain elements
that arise with different probabilities.

In the last part of the talk,
we'll consider geometric setting. So we're given data drawn from some
high dimensional distribution.

little data to understand the geometric structure of the distribution, so

What can we hope to say about

distribution that maximizes likelihood
of drawing exactly what we observed.

However, it does not capture the

we saw three different species of fish.

Maybe there's a fourth species or
a fifth species of fish in the ocean. The empirical distribution does

So there are a few natural questions. So one is,

of the distribution? Can we hope to say anything about it?

As we'll see the answer is yes. We can actually say very

So in some sense the motivation for
my work, or the inspiration for my work on these problems goes back to very early
work of R.A. Fisher, and Allen Turing

So in the case of Fisher, he was given

So Corbet spent a year in the Malaysian

Well, the left-most spike represents

he discovered or
he caught 110 species of butterflies.

And of these 110 species of butterflies, he only ever saw individuals from them,

The third spike represents the fact

So he sent his data to Ari Fisher,

I'm thinking about staying for
another year in the jungle, can you tell me how many new
species you think I would discover

if I catch butterflies at the same
rate as I did during my first year. And it actually turns out that there is
a extremely accurate estimate for this.

So, if you compute this alternating sum. So, take the total number of
species you've seen exactly once,

subtract the number of species you've
observed twice, add the number of species you've seen three times, subtract
the number you've seen four times.

Compute this alternating sum. And this gives an essentially
unbiased estimate

of the total number of new species
you would expect to discover in the same time period if you're
collecting butterflies at the same rate.

And again, this assumes nothing other
than the fact that you're collecting butterflies at the same rate and that the underlying distribution
of butterflies is fixed.

on the British World War II effort.

They were interested in

Divide that by the number of
